author: CaezarVII
body:
Strictly as a broker:

1. Fidelity is the best all round broker by a small margin because you get cash on your sweep account without having to manually move into money market. Vanguard also pays cash (more than Fidelity) on their sweep accounts but Vanguard is lacking in the technology department as far as their app and web platform so I prefer Fidelity.
2. Most of the other brokers don't really have enough differentiating factors in my opinion to say one is "better" than another. Vanguard is great, but their technology is lacking. Between the others, they all have easy to use apps and websites. Etrade, Schwab, and Ally tend to have the better website platforms and highly rated Android and iPhone apps. IBKR and possibly TD Ameritrade are good for advanced traders. If you don't go with fidelity, I would literally just choose based on which app or web platform you like the most.

Broker plus other banking services:

* The Fidelity rewards 2% cashback credit card is good enough to serve as a primary credit card. For this reason, combining your broker and credit card platform both at Fidelity for simplicity is a good option. Fidelity also offers a checking account with fee free/reimbursed ATM usage but their checking account platform is not as good as Schwab or BoA.
* Schwab is a great all round broker. Although they do not pay cash on sweep accounts, their easy to use and fee free/reimbursed checking accounts make up for it. I personally use Schwab for brokerage and checking (and an Amex credit card).
* Ally Invest should be way more popular than it is. Their saving account rates speak for themselves so combining Ally savings/checking/brokerage accounts is a win win win situation. Their web platform for brokerage is also excellent and might be my favorite overall. They also have a large ATM network and will reimburse up to $10 in ATM fees per month.
* Etrade offers a checking account with unlimited free ATM usage and fee reimbursement and a competitive rate Savings account. Etrade's offerings are very similar to Ally Invest in my opinion. I don't know how one would choose between the two except that I like Ally's website and app more. With things changing so quickly at brokers right now, I'm not sure that Ally Invest, or especially Etrade, are sustainable. I could see Etrade being acquired very soon. This is another reason why I stick with Schwab.
* Merrill Edge combined with their Preferred Rewards program is excellent and if you have enough assets with them you get up to 5.25% cash back on a no annual fee credit card for a category of your choice, 3.5% cash back on groceries, and 1.75% cashback on everything else. You really can't beat this. If you have enough assets with BoA/Merrile Edge, you also get unlimited ATM fee free/reimbursed.
* Chase YouInvest is a decent platform but it feels really new and not fully fleshed out. They only added options trading a few months ago I believe and they definitely have the most basic platform being only a couple notches above Robinhood as far as features which can be a good and bad thing since it is pretty simple to use. Now that they have options trading, I would recommend Chase YouInvest, especially if you are going to combine your assets at Chase. Like BoA Merrill Edge, you have to have a certain amount of assets with Chase to get fee free ATM usage with reimbursement.
* TD Ameritrade is a great brokers with nothing much to offer by way of banking features or their own investment products. Because of this I am not surprised that TD was acquired. They have an advanced trading platform but I'm not sure that it's worth it since they have below average app reviews on Android. I basically use my phone for everything and so the app is really important to me. For these reasons TD Ameritrade didn't really stand out to me.

\*\*One other caveat....if you trade inverse and leveraged ETFs such as UVXY or TQQQ, respectively, certain brokers do not allow trading of these securities. Vanguard and Chase do not allow trading of either. Merrill Edge does not allow trading of inverse ETFs. If not for this I would probably be with Merrill Edge in order to get the 5.25% cashback credit card or Chase to utilize their credit cards and checking account. I know Fidelity and Schwab allow trading of either leveraged or inverse ETFs, but I am not sure about the other brokers.

\*\*\*I have personally used Vanguard, Fidelity, Schwab, and Chase YouInvest extensively. I have experimented with Merrill Edge, Ally Invest, and Etrade.

If you are going with a REIT ETF make sure their geographic and property holdings match your objectives.  I trade with Fidelity and I like FREL ETF as a good general REIT hold.  No transaction fees, and it’s generated many good dividends for me over time.

author: ChekovsWorm
body:
A few thoughts on Fidelity vs Schwab, which I agree are likely the best choices for most people. I've used and continue to use both, but I lean towards Fidelity personally.

1)  Fidelity has a few benefits over Schwab, for an all around financial supermarket.  

a) ATM rebates on the Cash Management Account are next business day, same day the ATM withdrawal fully processes. Schwab is at month end.  

b) Fidelity does have a 1% foreign transaction fee listed on their Visa Debit ATM card, but both personal experience in dozens of countries and many reports online are that there is no fee on cash withdrawals at ATMs, only on Visa purchases. So for domestic use or for foreign cash withdrawal use, it's just as good as Schwab Bank Visa Debit, maybe better because of the next-day rebate.

c) Both firms are essentially $1 minimum for investments in own-brand mutual funds, both index and active for Fido (mostly $1 for index, $100 for active Schwab funds.) So really easy to get started. But when Fidelity got rid of minimums on their own mutual funds, they also got rid of minimums for monthly automatic  investing in them. When Schwab reduced minimum fund investments to $1 for the initial investment, they still kept the monthly automatic investment minimum as $100. So at Fidelity you can do, for example, a total of $70 allocated to two funds or three funds (or even less) as a fully automated monthly investment from your bank. At Schwab, you can't even do one fund on an automatic investment for that amount, it would have to be $100 per fund. Even for the $1 minimum funds. 

Both are still way better than Vanguard's $3000 minimum investment for most of their mutual funds ($1000 for target date funds.)

d) Fidelity has better CD laddering tools for brokered CDs than Schwab. Fidelity also has the same $1 per $1000 bond (which includes secondary brokered CDs) commission, but does not have Schwab's 10-bond (so $10) minimum commission. 

e) Last time I compared, Fidelity had more advanced order types such as trailing limits by both $ or %, and bracketing buy/sell ranges, which they call "Trade Armor", right on their web interface, than does Schwab. You can do that with Schwab's Streetsmart desktop trading tool but that's more complicated.

f) Any Fidelity-branded Money Market Fund in your non-retirement Fidelity account (trading or CMA), even if not your sweep fund, is immediately available as same-day available to withdraw, cover checks, debits, or ATM use (and in most cases, purchases) without having to sell the fund and wait till the next business day for it to be available. Further, the total of you cash, sweep fund, and purchased Fidelity money market funds in your trading account can be linked to be overflow immediately available cash in the Cash Management Account. Schwab doesn't have anything like that - Schwab MMFs tend to pay a basis point or two more than equivalent Fidelity ones, but you have to manually buy them, and manually sell them and wait till next day for the proceeds to be available to withdraw, and then transfer it to Schwab Bank to use on the ATM Debit card. 

2) Schwab has a few benefits over Fidelity for an all-around financial supermarket.

a) ATM Visa Debit Card is totally no-fee, even for purchases. And that's true both for the Schwab Bank Visa Debit card and the separate and issued only on-request Schwab Brokerage Account Visa Debit Card. At Fidelity the free unlimited ATM rebates are only on the Visa Debit Card issued on the Cash Management Account. If you want only the main trading "Fidelity Account" or want both, and want a card on the trading account, that is not free ATM rebates unless you are a high-net-worth private client or do a lot of paid trades. 

b) Customer service is good to excellent at both firms, and all US based, 24/7/365, but in my experience I think Schwab is a tiny bit better. 

c) Despite the lack of full integration between Schwab Brokerage and Schwab Bank for instant use and same day setttlement of MMFs, it's still all run by Schwab, so no chance of finger-pointing or handoff to another firm's support. 

That's not the case at Fidelity, where the often mis-named on Reddit "bank" (the CMA) is really a limited, checking-specific but legally brokerage account. Entirely managed by Fidelity in terms of you can't directly talk to the other banks involved, but there are up to about 20-25 outside banks really handling different parts of operating the checking account function. PNC Mellon Bank runs the actual Visa Debit Card portion. UMB Bank runs the check clearing and routing number for direct deposit/debit part of the account. Up to 4 outside banks out of a total at any time of around 20, hold your cash once it's been in Fidelity overnight. 

At Schwab, all of that is Schwab Bank, or the other Schwab-owned bank they bought in 2018, or Schwab Brokerage. All part of the Charles Schwab Corporation. The only part outsourced is BillPay, which is done by CheckFree, just like almost ever other bank, credit union, and brokerage (including Fidelity.)

I've rarely had support issues on either the Fidelity CMA checking or the Fidelity CMA Visa Debit, but when I have, and called Fidelity, I had to be transferred to the Fidelity checking (UMB) or Fidelity Debit Card (PNC) support teams. During business hours they answer as "Fidelity (name of service)" but one time on a weekend when an ATM transaction failed to give me money but debited it, I called and got the "PNC Bank Card Services" weekend support where the firstline rep didn't understand that I did not have a PNC account number and it was a Fidelity account. Still got it resolved but it was a bit of a hassle and a risk.

author: TheDarkOne32
body:
Depends on the person really.  You said you like to use your phone for trading, and I know Vanguard gets a lot of complaints about their outdated website and app, so maybe a switch is right for you.

I personally use Fidelity because they offer the credit card with 2 percent cash back, 24/7 client services (I'm a 3rd shift worker), their website is top-of-the-line, and they always solve any issues I am having.  A lot of people are jumping to Fidelity because they offer slightly cheaper index funds than Vanguard, but that really does not factor for me.  At this point, they're all so cheap that we're talking about nickles and dimes.

At the same time, if I had a friend who did not know a lot about investing, I would send him to Vanguard...either using a Target date fund or their Robo Advisor with a human contact.  Their advisory services are less expensive than Fidelity or Schwab, and they are not going to trip you up with any high fee funds and services that you might find at their competition if you are not paying attention.  A great example of this would be the target date funds at Fidelity.  Look at the expense ratio differences in the Fidelity Freedom funds and the Fidelity Freedom Index funds.  Vanguard just offers the low cost, better version.  Vanguard is very straight forward, simple, and almost boring.  That is how investing should be.

Vanguard actively managed funds are also cheaper and VDIGX would very appealing to me.   Their money market also has a higher return.  Schwab's money market return is almost laughable.

author: Cruian
body:
Will this be a tax advantaged account (such as IRA) or taxable account? Especially if this is a tax advantaged account, Fidelity and Schwab offer $1 initial minimums on their mutual funds, their index ones have some of the lowest expense ratios available right now. They're also 2 of the 3 preferred brokerages of /r/personalfinance.

&#x200B;

It sounds like penny stocks generally aren't reccommeneded: [https://www.reddit.com/r/investing/comments/ekhxyk/is\_there\_ever\_valid\_cases\_for\_investing\_in/](https://www.reddit.com/r/investing/comments/ekhxyk/is_there_ever_valid_cases_for_investing_in/)

&#x200B;

>ETFs and/or Index funds

Many ETFs are index funds.

Index fund or actively managed describes how the contents are chosen. ETF or mutual fund describes how it trades. You can pair either method of choosing contents with either method of trading for 4 possible combinations.

Meaning when muni bonds go on auction sometimes the minimum bid is 100k+, and possibly the secondary market just isn't there because no one is selling or there are too few sellers its just not worth to list them.

Also on fidelity and schwab they kind of hide a lot of bonds lower than a AA, mostly because lots of people are ignorant on bonds and think bonds=safe then might see a bond paying 10% interest and think thats a safe way to earn 10% (not realizing its rating is like CCC)

author: MasterCookSwag
body:
So here's the thing first and foremost go back and check what you're reporting here because to my knowledge there's no such thing as an "American funds Washington mutual 500 index".  There's 500 index funds and there's definitely an active fund called the American funds Washington mutual investors fund but I've never heard of what you're saying and it's not coming up on a search.

More importantly: the average American fund expense ratio usually sits anywhere from ~50 basis points to 1.5%.  Why the variance?  Advisor compensation is built in to various share classes.  Sure some of it has to do with scale: ie if you invest 100MM you get a cheaper fund than if you invest $100.  But you can buy the A shares of most American funds load waived and have around 60-80bps in expenses.  While that's not "cheap" it's not like criminal or whatever.

So that said Advisors are paid one of two ways(generally speaking) they charge a direct fee to the client or the products they're selling provide kickbacks.  The latter is likely what you're seeing here given how much higher the expenses that you're seeing are vs the expenses one can get if they just go to like fidelity or whatever and buy the fund.  Part of this is the fact that retirement plan administration is expensive but the other part is that the advisor comp is likely tied directly in to the fund.

So realistically if you're a small business you have three choices: do it yourself and assume all fiduciary duties in a pooled product, use an advisor that's going to give you optimal fund choices then charge their fee on top of that, go with someone getting paid by the funds they're selling.  I'm biased but imo #2 is the best here given that the employer will be able to say "I paid 0.95% to an advisor and the average expenses of the fund were 0.15% vs" the expenses were 1.1% and who knows how that actually breaks down.  Your employer clearly went with option three.

Make of that what you will.  A retirement plan can potentially still make sense even if the returns are bogged by expenses given the tax deferral but there's certainly better ways to implement then what you're seeing, at least based off the very limited picture you've painted.

author: 80slaserbackground
body:
I keep about 5k in RH just for options. When I get a really good gain and my balance gets above 15k I move it to one of my Fidelity accounts and put it in stocks. 

I hit 2 commas in cash + equity about a year ago. My 401k and IRA are in boring blue chips and mostly DRIP stocks. Once I've got enough passive income to equal 60 of my paychecks or if I hit roughly 3m in stocks I'll quit my day job. I'll probably still keep my consulting business and keep my RH account for options since it's fun to me. 

Right now I've got about 3 paychecks per year from dividend stocks and about 5 paychecks from  my rental properties. Right now all of that is being reinvested (went to look at a potential 3 family this morning) and my family eats and vacations only on my wife and my combined salaries.

Many here dislike the Vanguard website interface, but I don't mind it one bit. I'm accustomed to it and understand where every setting is located. 

Most of my assets are with Vanguard and I have my 401k at Fidelity. Either broker is solid. I've heard Schwab is great too. 

All 3 offer cheap funds that track all the major indices. Can't go wrong with any of them. 

Vanguard today announced commission free stock trades while ETFs were already free to trade. Very pleased to wake up to this news.

author: Ltjenkins
body:
Depends if you are allowed to. Do you still work for the company? If so, many plans do not allow you to do in service rollovers. 

If you are looking to roll the 401k to an IRA because you no longer work for the company that sponsored the 401k, Vanguard is a good option. Fidelity also has zero commission trading and their indexed options are comparable to Vanguard. Between the two companies it seems like just personal preference currently.

author: BaltimoreProud
body: It makes sense if Vanguard is offering a product you want to use and Fidelity doesn't have a comparable one. If you just invest in a S&P 500 index fund rolling over doesn't really make sense because both companies offer that and the fee for them is roughly the same amount.

author: GaylrdFocker
body:
If you can invest $800 / month does round up actually help at all?  Just put in $810 per month to M1 and get rid of Acorns. M1 is perfectly fine.

That said, I have more than 1, but only actively invest with 1. I have a Fidelity credit card so have an account with them, but only have it open to roll my cash back into. My USAA account is the only one I actively use.

author: dvdmovie1
body: I agree with u/GaylrdFocker I don't get the appeal of RH/CA at this point. Go to Fidelity, Etrade, Ameritrade and get free trades with actual features and better customer service.

author: xler3
body:
I like robinhood because they instantly approved me for full options. 

my regular broker, fidelity, still hasn't approved me.

author: Darxe
body: I have a friend who works for Fidelity. They all know about it and think this place is hilarious

author: UnstimulatingBeth
body: He never worked at fidelity

author: Cruss127
body: Arent most of the big ones 0 commision? I use Fidelity for inatance.

author: SirGlass
body:
well once you hit that minimum you can invest any additional amount you want.

In the past some would waive the minimum if you agreed to for example invest $X amount per pay period or something like that however I heard vanguard stopped doing that. However like I said, schwab and fidelity have 1000s of mutual funds with $1 minimums you probably could find a nearly equivalent fund with them

author: Cruian
body: Over at /r/personalfinance, the top 3 recommendations for IRAs are Fidelity, Schwab, or Vanguard. All have free trades on US listed stocks and most ETFs and all offer very low expense ratio index mutual funds.

author: Jakeep16
body: Fidelity is great in every aspect

author: PapaCharlie9
body:
No, your Fidelity account is fine. You can buy Vanguard products with your Fidelity account.

Generally, there’s really no reason to voluntarily open a Vanguard account anymore.

author: Pleaseexcuseyou
body:
Webull, they have options and you can even loan out shares for others to short and you can short stocks. 

They also give you 3x day trade buying power 

Not as stupid simple as robinhood but not as full of useless shit like  tos or fidelity 

Also...webull will give you lv 3 options without too many questions

author: 4pooling
body:
Prime cap is a fantastic fund (mid/large cap growth). 

Wish it was open to retail investors in individual accounts like me. I have most of my assets with Vanguard in a Roth IRA and taxable. 

My 401k only offers Fidelity funds. 

The 2055 retirement fund is good too.  As you age it will increase bond exposure. Nice thing is any retirement target date fund (especially Vanguard ones) include exposure to US/international stocks and bonds.

author: MakeMyDayGypsy
body: I have used Fidelity, Schwab, and E-trade. I use primarily E-trade with 1 account at Schwab. I thin E-trade is a solid online platform with a really nice, more advanced desktop app. I have checking, HYSA, roth IRA, tradional IRA, 2 brokerage accounts through E-trade. Schwab probably has the best customer service in finance. E-trade for the more advanced investor. Schwab for the newer one who needs to ask questions.

author: In4matics
body:
Research the following platforms:  Vanguard, Fidelity, M1 Finance, WiFi for ETF, Index Fund, and Mutual fund invest. Find one you like.

Find a high-interest savings account that meets your needs.

Edit typo

author: cport1
body: Fidelity for 401k and IRA and TDA for equity / option trading

author: mothumann
body: I don't know what your specific situation is, but selling options around ex-dividend dates can be dangerous for what sounds like the reason you're describing. [This page from Fidelity is worth a read](https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/investment-products/options/dividends-options-assignment-risk); especially the part called "Other considerations and risks" toward the bottom. The gist of it is that you can be stuck paying the dividend amount times the number of shares involved in your options contracts if you're not careful.

author: dalalarman
body:
Honestly this is the biggest factor why I'm not sure whether I want to maintain most of my assets moving forward with vanguard or not.

My other institution is Fidelity, and their interface is defintely more user friendly right now.

author: Cruian
body: Free trades for Vanguard (and any) ETF, $75 for mutual funds from anyone other than Fidelity.

author: msgidol
body: Wish they would lower their expense ratios on the index funds slightly to be more competitive with Fidelity and Schwab.

author: onlydateunstablehoes
body: On TOS desktop app, go to trade, and there should be a clickable menu near the bottom (below all the option expiries) that says "options time and sales." Dunno how to do it on the app, though, and I don't trade options in my Fidelity account

author: AxeCapitalx
body: I have fidelity... But my buddy has had good things to say about Charles Schwab

author: BurninCrab
body: If it helps as a reference point, I have around $300k with Fidelity and it gives me the performance tab

author: iWOCuplikethis
body: I am suggesting you use a computer to best do your research and not fat finger your trades. The major brokers are going commission free too. You could be using fidelity, interactive brokers, or schwab for free as well.

author: Laminar_flo
body:
A lot of them are simply gone or are now private and don’t report anything. 

The big public ones that quit (WMT, TJX, ROST, M and many more) did so at the request of big instutional investors like Fidelity, TRowe, Welly, CapRe, etc bc monthly comps introduced ST volatility that the big funds felt was ‘unnecessary’. The plain English version is that monthly comps induced hedge funds to whip in and out of retailers, which caused headaches for ultra-long term holders. Honestly a better question is why COST is still doing it.

author: Cruian
body: But Fidelity offers a great selection of their own mutual funds that are free to trade. Their index ones have extremely low expense ratios, even lower than Vanguard's in most cases.

author: stdubbs
body: Can't go wrong with buying the market. SPY/SPYG/SPYV or the Fidelity/Prudential trackers.

author: vin786
body: SPY is a ETF buy it for 6k and hang on to it. Next buy Fidelity contrafund

author: Luka-Step-Back
body: At one point, IBM sold orders of magnitude more computers than Apple.

author: flex674
body: IBM was bad. GE was a nightmare.

author: mwbbrown
TheSavingsGuy
body:
While Buffett is my idol, he has made some mistakes. 

He famously bought a stake in IBM (which floundered while the rest of the market soared) and then later sold it. 

Buffett also sold Disney stock years ago and missed out on the gains of the past couple decades.

author: frameworkfortune
body: Well for budget investors, amatuers, new investors etc it might matter. Not everyone has a ton of money to invest, and if they want to invest in VR but can't afford Facebook maybe they can get a couple of shares of Sony. If I did a top 5 tech stocks in general the obvious overly talked about stocks Amazon, IBM, Facebook, etc. would be on there and it wouldn't be as interesting.

author: STRAT0CAST3R
body:
23 years old, new to investing. Have about 2k in my portfolio, would love to hear how I'm doing:  


IBM - 26%

MSFT - 24%

BYND - 25%

PYPL - 11%

DIS - 7%

BEP - 7%

author: realister
body: JAN 21 is when it starts for big Tech. IBM and Netflix reporting.

author: ahsanali65
body: Definitely agree that not all tech companies are created equal. IBM and Oracle are not stocks I'm interested in. Facebook, Google, and Netflix are all kinda "meh" to me compared to the other FAANGS. Trying to capture all of what I want will be pretty hard apparently.

author: return_of_the_ring
body: It is risky... Some of Buffet's bets have not panned out as expected and he missed the boat on quite a few tech stocks. Eg: his investment into IBM was a failure.

author: coderntrader
body:
$MSFT, $AMZN, $IBM, and $GOOG already have commercial AI offerings. They are mainly aimed at businesses and they are rolling them into existing offerings and charging more. For example, AI for your sales data or security logs. 

Here's an example from $MSFT that even lists some of their customers ($UBER and others):

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/cognitive-services/

author: unspoken_arrangement
body:
I use a combination of seeking alpha(free version) and stock twits(mostly shit) to get broad strokes and then do more detailed research from there. 

While the current generation are both powered by AMD APUs all the previous three generations have been a mixture of ATI/Nvidia/Intel/IBM CPUs and GPUs. All to say that AMD getting the contracts for the next generation was not necessarily a guarantee but gives further confidence in their Zen 2 architecture.

author: Mdizzle29
body:
Your “genius“ hasn’t done that much lately. No investment in tech other than IBM (lol) will bring poor returns. His investment style is passé. I was up 93% last year. Who’s the genius now? 

https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/warren-buffett-berkshire-hathaway-cant-beat-stock-market-2019-5-1028178282

https://www.marketwatch.com/story/no-one-will-ask-this-one-question-hanging-over-berkshire-hathaways-annual-meeting-2019-05-03

author: mikes703
body: Haha just asked my friend who works at IBM and at data warehouses, he’s never even seen AMD.  Both of us are IS majors, I don’t work in that industry.  He says companies will lean towards intel anyway.

author: CallMeAnanda
body: It might take 10 years, but it's coming. The switch will have started in 5. Necessary x86 shit will be emulated or run offsite. Software will be developed and maintained in one place - no more splitting resources between PC and mobile. Expect an ARM macbook in the next 2-3 years and as soon as it's announced, everybody else will see the writing on the wall. AMD and Intel will both tank and be bought by IBM. Trust me. I'm from the future.

author: Fenix04
body:
>1. The jokes on you. I have a BS and a MBA. My role has always been a technical one in a financial services firm.

This quote explains why you think IBM is a tech company.  You pretty much just said "I'm in a technical role at a company who's IT department is stuck in the 80's" (90's if you're lucky).  I worked as a software engineer at a top financial services company for 6 years.  IBM and Oracle make Bank on financial services via support contracts.

Is your mainframe running? Because the 80's would like it back...

author: Jordykins850
body: Sell ConocoPhillips calls at open. Probably pick up gold, oil and a tech hedge near close (prob IBM).

author: silence9
body: What you probably don't realize is that google and ibm also have cloud services. Aws was just first so it's more fleshed out in terms of ease of getting started. Learn aws, but use something else in the long run.

author: TravelingArthur
body: Just a heads up. They said the same thing about General Electric, Bear Sterns, Lehman Brothers and IBM

author: StockDealer
body:
You just keep popping your head up like whack-a-mole with new names and new businesses. Jenson runs NVDA, and he's not just a CEO, it's literally his baby and he was the founder. He makes the decisions.

Like Musk, for the most part, makes the decisions about Tesla. BOD's, for firms that do engineering, are very important if you have a shitty MBA at the helm. You need to have engineers on them to balance out the MBA's lack of knowledge.

Okay, you barfed out IBM -- let's take a look. They aren't really a bleeding edged tech firm, they're a government consultant for the most part. So, not really relevant here. Yes yes, I know, deep blue, blah blah blah. No, they're not actually a silicon valley tech firm. They're the Sears of the tech world. They're just in it for the contracts. So sure, run them with MBA's. 

Bill Gates was a criminal, not a good engineer. His firm stole code, just as one of many examples. He thought the Internet was a fad, before he said he predicted that it would be great. 640K should be enough for anybody, he said, and yes, he did say it. His firm was a gang that instituted a "new computer tax" and it made him money. Nothing to do with engineering. He didn't get where he was because his company made great software. Nobody would argue that. If you want to run a successful *software* company you need people who know software.

You just keep going on and on... Job's secret weapon was the Woz. And no, Apple was not a bleeding edged tech company (with the exception of three products: the original Apple, then 20 years later the Lisa, and then the iPhone) it became a design studio, and Jobs was a fucking excellent designer. See how that works? You want to run a successful  design studio you should be a designer.

Tell me about couch companies next. Guess what? To run a couch company you should have people who know about couches.

author: NexoExo
body:
You are beyond stupid. 

1. The CEO of AMD is JENSEN Huang. 

2. It doesn't matter if he's the founder, you dumb fuck. We are talking about the Board. Do you know what the job of a BOD is?

3. Okay, IBM is not a tech company. Why? Because it doesn't suit your argument. Go tell the rest of the world that. 

4. Right, Bill Gates owes everything to him being a thief.

5. Wozniak had nothing to do with Apple 2.0. That is, the iPod era to current. Look at the share price performance in that period of time. The BOD has never had more than 1-2 engineer's during this period of time. 

It's important to learn when you're wrong. Look up what the responsibility of a board is and why they're seldom (if ever) comprised of engineers. You need a very foundational education in this very basic topic if you are indeed a "stock dealer".

author: mwbbrown
body:
> But they will be in EVERYTHING going forward.

If I asked you if IBM would be a major player in tech 20 years ago you would have said "of course", if I had asked you if the online book seller [Amazon.com](https://Amazon.com) would have been a massive player in tech you would have given me an answer like "of course, their website will be even bigger". but today Amazon is almost 10 times larger then IBM. 

Same with something like Facebook and HP. Facebook didn't exist 20 years ago, and HP is a shell of it's former self. 

I agree that information technology is revolutionizing everything, but it isn't a given that today's big tech companies will reap the benefits. Google might have the best self driving tech today, but it might be a commodity in 10 years and the real strengths is knowing how to build a car and having the experience to comply with 120 countries worth of bureaucracy so Ford could win. 

&#x200B;

My point is, if you want to make money over the next 20 years with one investment made today, I would still stick with a total market position, rather then locking myself into one sector of the market.

author: Jigsus
body:
Sundar Pichai is 100% to blame for this. He's just there to "realize value". That means he will bleed google dry until there's no more value to be pumped out of it to the detriment of innovation and disruption. 

His number one mission is stock price and you can see it. Literally on the the day it was decided that he'd take over the nature of the stock changed from a steady constant slow grower to a "live by the earning calls" swinging machine: https://i.imgur.com/XpnBcoV.png

He's a wall street man not a revolutionary. He's the guy the board brings in after the founders are out. A pure successor CEO. You can see this in the tech industry over and over again with disaters like Gil Amelio or successes like Larry Probst. 

This is the typical [founder dilemma](https://hbr.org/2008/02/the-founders-dilemma) that hit Google very late because they had an overly long growth phase. Eric Schmidt was smart enough to keep this alive even though he was a wall street man too by delegating all the tech to the founders. 

So what does this mean? For me it means I'll keep trading Google stock by using classic indicators (money). There is no crash coming. It's just going to be a typical big tech company like IBM.

author: Jordykins850
body: IBM
